did.unittitle: Papers regarding Abraham Feingold's Prosecution For Alleged Communist Sympathies
did.abstract: Newspaper clippings concerning the trial, correspondence and pamphlets written in support of Feingold, and other documents relating to Feingold's career and dismissal.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: In May of 1950, Abraham Feingold, a mathematics teacher at Manual Training High School in Brooklyn, was suspended from his job for refusing to answer a question, submitted by the superintendent of schools to all New York City school teachers, as to whether he was or had ever been a communist. Feingold was one of eight New York City teachers who refused to answer the question. All were suspended by the superintendent of schools. In the fall of that year, the suspensions were upheld, and on appeal by the State Education Commissioner, Abraham Feingold and the seven other defendants were permanently removed from the New York school system.

In addition to refusing to answer the question as to past or present communist affiliation, all eight defendants were Jewish, and charges of anti-Semitism on the part of the superintendent of schools were prominent throughout the controversy.

Abraham Feingold was born in Ukraine on March 20, 1900 and moved to the United Sattes when he was 9 years old. He received his BA from COlumbia Univeristy, and his Master's of Education from Teachers College of Columbia University. He passed away on SPetember 14, 1970.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection includes newspaper clippings concerning the trial, correspondence and pamphlets written in support of Feinberg, and other documents relating to Feingold's career and dismissal.

The collection includes pamphlets written by supporters of the defendants; newspaper articles pertaining to suspensions and subsequent trial; petitions condemning the suspension of Feingold, declarations in support of the eight teachers; open letters by the eight to the Board of Education and parents of students explaining their position. Also included are numerous letters written to Feingold from former students, associates, and parents expressing support; teaching evaluations; notes of appreciation from superiors to Feingold; copies of citations received by Feingold for commendable service in the War Loan Drive (1944); and copies of speeches (final and rough drafts) delivered by Feingold at a press conference in Geneva, Switzerland and before the National Federation of Education Workers (CGT) in Paris (1950).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In addiiton to personal writings, this folder includes summaries of what various teachers were accused of during the Red Scare, a statement that seems to be a transcript of what Mr. Feingold said in court in response to the charges against him, and various pieces of correspondence with and articles written by B.Z. Goldberg.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The clippings cover the trials of the teachers. Also included are obituaries of those teahcers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains pamphlets printed by the Teachers' Union of the City of New York. Topics covered include academic freedom, the attacks on teachers, and excerpts from court proceedings. Also included is a French language newspaper, "Voix Ouvrière" [The Workers' Voice] reporting on the persecution of teachers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contians numerous pieces of correspondence from around the world in support of Feingold. There are also a few examples of negative correspondence. The folder also contains evidence of Mr. Feingold's service and patriotism, including a copy of his honorable discharge from the U.S. Army and his donations to the Red Cross and other charities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains the various exemplary performance reports Mr. Feingold recieved during his career as a New York City teacher.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains speeches given in Geneva and Paris on the circumstances of his trial and persecution during the Red Scare. There is also a speech about the salary struggles faced by teachers in the United States. Newspapers from France and Switzerland with articles on his speeches are also found in this folder.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains reports about the targeted teachers, reprints of articles from the New York Times, statements in support of the teachers, missives from the union requesting the reinstatement of the teachers, and other open letters to supprtive community groups. Also included is a transcript of questions asked of Mr. Feingold's sueprvisor Mr. Malament, the head of the math department at Manual Training High School.
